To have made the same abatement to them all, would have been the easy, but not the equitable, course. Now the noblest part, according to my estimate, is to pursue justice in one’s domestic as well as public conduct; in minute as in great affairs; and in our own, as well as in other men’s concerns. For if “all sins are equal,'' ⁰ so are all meritorious actions.

Accordingly, Ι remitted to all in general one- eighth part of the price they had agreed to give me, that none “without my largesse might depart'’; next, I made separate provision for those who had invested large sums in their purchase3 since they had not only contributed more to my profit, but lost more heavily. To those, therefore, who had bought to the value of more than ten thousand sesterces, I remitted (over and beside the general and, so to speak, public eighth) a tenth part of what they had paid above that sum. l don’t know whether I express myself clearly enough; sol will set out my reckoning more plainly. Suppose a man had pur- chased to the value of fifteen thousand sesterces, he got back one-eighth part of that amount, plus one-tenth of five thousand sesterces
